However, tool learning is hampered by the static synthetic data pipelines where data generation and model training are executed as two separate, non-interactive processes. This approach fails to adaptively focus on a model's specific weaknesses and allows noisy labels to persist, degrading training efficiency. We introduce LoopTool, a fully automated, model-aware data evolution framework that closes this loop by tightly integrating data synthesis and model training. LoopTool iteratively refines both the data and the model through three synergistic modules: (1) Greedy Capability Probing (GCP) diagnoses the model's mastered and failed capabilities; (2) Judgement-Guided Label Verification (JGLV) uses an open-source judge model to find and correct annotation errors, progressively purifying the dataset; and (3) Error-Driven Data Expansion (EDDE) generates new, challenging samples based on identified failures. This closed-loop process operates within a cost-effective, open-source ecosystem, eliminating dependence on expensive closed-source APIs. Experiments show that our 8B model trained with LoopTool significantly surpasses its 32B data generator and achieves new state-of-the-art results on the BFCL-v3 and ACEBench benchmarks for its scale. Our work demonstrates that closed-loop, self-refining data pipelines can dramatically enhance the tool-use capabilities of LLMs.

item.title: LocalBench: Benchmarking LLMs on County-Level Local Knowledge and Reasoning
item.content:encoded: arXiv:2511.10459v2 Announce Type: replace-cross Abstract: Large language models (LLMs) have been widely evaluated on macro-scale geographic tasks, such as global factual recall, event summarization, and regional reasoning. Yet, their ability to handle hyper-local knowledge remains poorly understood. This gap is increasingly consequential as real-world applications, from civic platforms to community journalism, demand AI systems that can reason about neighborhood-specific dynamics, cultural narratives, and local governance. Existing benchmarks fall short in capturing this complexity, often relying on coarse-grained data or isolated references. We present LocalBench, the first benchmark designed to systematically evaluate LLMs on county-level local knowledge across the United States. Grounded in the Localness Conceptual Framework, LocalBench includes 14,782 validated question-answer pairs across 526 U.S. counties in 49 states, integrating diverse sources such as Census statistics, local subreddit discourse, and regional news. It spans physical, cognitive, and relational dimensions of locality. Using LocalBench, we evaluate 13 state-of-the-art LLMs under both closed-book and web-augmented settings. Our findings reveal critical limitations: even the best-performing models reach only 56.8% accuracy on narrative-style questions and perform below 15.5% on numerical reasoning. Moreover, larger model size and web augmentation do not guarantee better performance, for example, search improves Gemini's accuracy by +13.6%, but reduces GPT-series performance by -11.4%. These results underscore the urgent need for language models that can support equitable, place-aware AI systems: capable of engaging with the diverse, fine-grained realities of local communities across geographic and cultural contexts.

item.title: A Style is Worth One Code: Unlocking Code-to-Style Image Generation with Discrete Style Space
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: visual stylization, style code, CoTyle, image generation, diffusion model

Summary: This paper addresses the challenge of generating novel and consistent visual styles in artistic creation. Traditional methods often rely on lengthy text prompts, reference images, or fine-tuning, which can lead to issues with style consistency and creativity. The study introduces the novel task of code-to-style image generation, which uses a numerical style code as the sole input for generating images with unique styles. CoTyle is proposed as the first open-source method for this task, bridging the gap in academic research. The approach begins with training a discrete style codebook from a collection of images to extract style embeddings, which serve as conditions for a text-to-image diffusion model (T2I-DM). An autoregressive style generator is then trained on these discrete embeddings to model their distribution, enabling the creation of new style embeddings. During inference, a numerical style code is mapped to an embedding that guides the T2I-DM in image generation. The key advantages of CoTyle include its simplicity and diversity, unlocking a broad range of reproducible styles from minimal input. Experimental results confirm that a numerical code can effectively control artistic styles, validating the authors' assertion that a style is worth one code.
arXiv:2511.10555v3 Announce Type: replace-cross Abstract: Innovative visual stylization is a cornerstone of artistic creation, yet generating novel and consistent visual styles remains a significant challenge. Existing generative approaches typically rely on lengthy textual prompts, reference images, or parameter-efficient fine-tuning to guide style-aware image generation, but often struggle with style consistency, limited creativity, and complex style representations. In this paper, we affirm that a style is worth one numerical code by introducing the novel task, code-to-style image generation, which produces images with novel, consistent visual styles conditioned solely on a numerical style code. To date, this field has only been primarily explored by the industry (e.g., Midjourney), with no open-source research from the academic community. To fill this gap, we propose CoTyle, the first open-source method for this task. Specifically, we first train a discrete style codebook from a collection of images to extract style embeddings. These embeddings serve as conditions for a text-to-image diffusion model (T2I-DM) to generate stylistic images. Subsequently, we train an autoregressive style generator on the discrete style embeddings to model their distribution, allowing the synthesis of novel style embeddings. During inference, a numerical style code is mapped to a unique style embedding by the style generator, and this embedding guides the T2I-DM to generate images in the corresponding style. Unlike existing methods, our method offers unparalleled simplicity and diversity, unlocking a vast space of reproducible styles from minimal input. Extensive experiments validate that CoTyle effectively turns a numerical code into a style controller, demonstrating a style is worth one code.

item.title: Glia: A Human-Inspired AI for Automated Systems Design and Optimization
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: AI, networked systems, large language models, design, distributed GPU cluster

Summary: This article introduces Glia, an AI architecture aimed at autonomously designing mechanisms for computer systems, leveraging the creativity and reasoning abilities akin to those of human experts. Glia employs large language models (LLMs) within a multi-agent workflow where each agent has a specialized role in reasoning, experimentation, and analysis. The collaboration between these agents occurs through an evaluation framework that integrates abstract reasoning with empirical feedback, diverging from conventional machine learning approaches that often optimize black-box solutions. The effectiveness of Glia is demonstrated through its application to a distributed GPU cluster dedicated to LLM inference, where it successfully develops novel algorithms for request routing, scheduling, and auto-scaling. Remarkably, these algorithms achieve performance levels comparable to human experts while significantly reducing the time required for development. Additionally, Glia provides insights into workload behavior that were previously unexplored. The findings of this research indicate that by aligning reasoning capabilities of LLMs with structured experimental processes, AI systems can yield creative, interpretable, and practical designs for complex system challenges.
arXiv:2510.27176v3 Announce Type: replace Abstract: Can an AI autonomously design mechanisms for computer systems on par with the creativity and reasoning of human experts? We present Glia, an AI architecture for networked systems design that uses large language models (LLMs) in a human-inspired, multi-agent workflow. Each agent specializes in reasoning, experimentation, and analysis, collaborating through an evaluation framework that grounds abstract reasoning in empirical feedback. Unlike prior ML-for-systems methods that optimize black-box policies, Glia generates interpretable designs and exposes its reasoning process. When applied to a distributed GPU cluster for LLM inference, it produces new algorithms for request routing, scheduling, and auto-scaling that perform at human-expert levels in significantly less time, while yielding novel insights into workload behavior. Our results suggest that by combining reasoning LLMs with structured experimentation, an AI can produce creative and understandable designs for complex systems problems.

item.title: SciAgent: A Unified Multi-Agent System for Generalistic Scientific Reasoning
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: SciAgent, multi-agent system, scientific reasoning, domain generality, expert performance

Summary: Recent developments in large language models have led to the creation of SciAgent, a multi-agent system tailored for generalistic scientific reasoning. SciAgent is structured as a hierarchical problem-solving process that includes a Coordinator Agent, which interprets problem domains and complexities. This Coordinator orchestrates specialized Worker Systems, comprising Sub-agents for tasks like symbolic deduction, conceptual modeling, numerical computation, and verification. These Sub-agents collaborate to create and refine reasoning pipelines specific to each task. SciAgent has demonstrated impressive capabilities by consistently achieving or exceeding the performance of human gold medalists in mathematics and physics Olympiads (IMO, IMC, IPhO, CPhO). Furthermore, its efficacy extends beyond these fields, having been successfully tested in the International Chemistry Olympiad (IChO) and selected problems from the Humanity's Last Exam (HLE) benchmark. This versatility confirms SciAgent's potential for generalization across various scientific disciplines. Overall, this work positions SciAgent as a significant advancement in the pursuit of generalistic scientific intelligence, enabling AI systems to perform coherent and cross-disciplinary reasoning at an expert level.
arXiv:2511.08151v2 Announce Type: replace Abstract: Recent advances in large language models have enabled AI systems to achieve expert-level performance on domain-specific scientific tasks, yet these systems remain narrow and handcrafted. We introduce SciAgent, a unified multi-agent system designed for generalistic scientific reasoning-the ability to adapt reasoning strategies across disciplines and difficulty levels. SciAgent organizes problem solving as a hierarchical process: a Coordinator Agent interprets each problem's domain and complexity, dynamically orchestrating specialized Worker Systems, each composed of interacting reasoning Sub-agents for symbolic deduction, conceptual modeling, numerical computation, and verification. These agents collaboratively assemble and refine reasoning pipelines tailored to each task. Across mathematics and physics Olympiads (IMO, IMC, IPhO, CPhO), SciAgent consistently attains or surpasses human gold-medalist performance, demonstrating both domain generality and reasoning adaptability. Additionally, SciAgent has been tested on the International Chemistry Olympiad (IChO) and selected problems from the Humanity's Last Exam (HLE) benchmark, further confirming the system's ability to generalize across diverse scientific domains. This work establishes SciAgent as a concrete step toward generalistic scientific intelligence-AI systems capable of coherent, cross-disciplinary reasoning at expert levels.

item.title: EHRStruct: A Comprehensive Benchmark Framework for Evaluating Large Language Models on Structured Electronic Health Record Tasks
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: EHRStruct, large language models, structured EHR data, benchmark evaluation, clinical tasks

Summary: This paper addresses the challenge of evaluating large language models (LLMs) on structured electronic health record (EHR) data, which is crucial for clinical decision-making but lacks standardized evaluation frameworks. To fill this gap, the authors introduce EHRStruct, a novel benchmark comprising 11 representative clinical tasks and 2,200 evaluation samples sourced from two prominent EHR datasets. EHRStruct enables systematic and comprehensive assessment of LLMs on structured EHR data tasks. The study evaluates 20 advanced LLMs, including both general-purpose and medical-specific models, to understand their performance on these tasks. The authors analyze several key factors influencing model effectiveness, such as different input formatting techniques, few-shot learning capabilities, and fine-tuning approaches. Additionally, they compare these models against 11 state-of-the-art LLM-based methods designed to enhance structured data reasoning. Findings reveal that many structured EHR tasks require sophisticated understanding and reasoning abilities beyond baseline LLM capabilities. To address these demands, the paper proposes EHRMaster, an innovative code-augmented method that achieves state-of-the-art performance on the EHRStruct benchmark, demonstrating promising practical utility in clinical AI applications.
arXiv:2511.08206v2 Announce Type: replace Abstract: Structured Electronic Health Record (EHR) data stores patient information in relational tables and plays a central role in clinical decision-making. Recent advances have explored the use of large language models (LLMs) to process such data, showing promise across various clinical tasks.However, the absence of standardized evaluation frameworks and clearly defined tasks makes it difficult to systematically assess and compare LLM performance on structured EHR data.To address these evaluation challenges, we introduce EHRStruct, a benchmark specifically designed to evaluate LLMs on structured EHR tasks.EHRStruct defines 11 representative tasks spanning diverse clinical needs and includes 2,200 task-specific evaluation samples derived from two widely used EHR datasets.We use EHRStruct to evaluate 20 advanced and representative LLMs, covering both general and medical models.We further analyze key factors influencing model performance, including input formats, few-shot generalisation, and finetuning strategies, and compare results with 11 state-of-the-art LLM-based enhancement methods for structured data reasoning. Our results indicate that many structured EHR tasks place high demands on the understanding and reasoning capabilities of LLMs.In response, we propose EHRMaster, a code-augmented method that achieves state-of-the-art performance and offers practical

item.title: On Geometric Structures for Policy Parameterization in Continuous Control
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: stochastic policies, continuous control, unit manifold, action generation, adaptive concentration

Summary: Standard stochastic policies in continuous control frequently use boundary-enforcing transformations such as tanh, which can adversely affect the optimization landscape and cause gradient issues. Alternative parameterizations on the unit manifold, like directional distributions, offer theoretical advantages but are often computationally expensive due to the need for special functions or rejection sampling methods. This paper introduces a novel and computationally efficient action generation approach that maintains the benefits of operating on the unit manifold. The method decomposes the action into a deterministic directional vector alongside a learnable concentration scalar, allowing efficient interpolation between the desired direction and uniform noise on the unit manifold. This design reduces the policy head parameters from 2d to d+1, nearly a 50% reduction, and keeps sampling complexity at a simple O(d) without costly procedures. Empirical results show the method matches or outperforms state-of-the-art techniques on common continuous control benchmarks, with especially notable improvements (+37.6% and +112%) on high-dimensional locomotion tasks. Ablation studies confirm that both unit-norm normalization and the adaptive concentration component are critical for the approach’s success. Overall, these findings highlight that respecting bounded action space structures explicitly leads to robust, efficient control, supplanting the need for complex unbounded distributions. Code is provided in the supplementary materials.
arXiv:2511.08234v2 Announce Type: replace Abstract: Standard stochastic policies for continuous control often rely on ad-hoc boundary-enforcing transformations (e.g., tanh) which can distort the underlying optimization landscape and introduce gradient pathologies. While alternative parameterizations on the unit manifold (e.g., directional distributions) are theoretically appealing, their computational complexity (often requiring special functions or rejection sampling) has limited their practical use. We propose a novel, computationally efficient action generation paradigm that preserves the structural benefits of operating on a unit manifold. Our method decomposes the action into a deterministic directional vector and a learnable concentration scalar, enabling efficient interpolation between the target direction and uniform noise on the unit manifold. This design can reduce policy head parameters by nearly 50\% (from $2d$ to $d+1$) and maintains a simple $O(d)$ sampling complexity, avoiding costly sampling procedures. Empirically, our method matches or exceeds state-of-the-art methods on standard continuous control benchmarks, with significant improvements (e.g., +37.6\% and +112\%) on high-dimensional locomotion tasks. Ablation studies confirm that both the unit-norm normalization and the adaptive concentration mechanism are essential to the method's success. These findings suggest that robust, efficient control can be achieved by explicitly respecting the structure of bounded action spaces, rather than relying on complex, unbounded distributions. Code is available in supplementary materials.

item.title: JobSphere: An AI-Powered Multilingual Career Copilot for Government Employment Platforms
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: JobSphere, Retrieval-Augmented Generation, multilingual, accessibility, government employment

Summary: This paper presents JobSphere, an AI-powered career assistant integrated into the Punjab government employment platform, PGRKAM, addressing common user challenges such as complex navigation, limited language options, and lack of personalized support. The system utilizes a Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) architecture, supporting English, Hindi, and Punjabi languages, thereby enhancing accessibility for diverse users. A notable technical innovation is the use of 4-bit quantization, which allows deployment on consumer-grade GPUs like the NVIDIA RTX 3050 4GB, reducing implementation costs by 89% compared to cloud-based solutions. JobSphere features voice-enabled interactions, automated mock tests, resume parsing with skills recognition, and an embedding-based job recommendation system that achieves a precision@10 score of 68%. Performance evaluations show a high factual accuracy rate of 94%, a median response time of 1.8 seconds, and a System Usability Scale score of 78.5/100, marking a 50% improvement over the existing PGRKAM platform. The system effectively bridges accessibility gaps for rural Punjab and Hindi-speaking users and ensures access to reliable job information from government sources, making it a significant advancement in public sector employment assistance.
arXiv:2511.08343v2 Announce Type: replace Abstract: Users of government employment websites commonly face engagement and accessibility challenges linked to navigational complexity, a dearth of language options, and a lack of personalized support. This paper introduces JobSphere, an AI-powered career assistant that is redefining the employment platform in Punjab called PGRKAM. JobSphere employs Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) architecture, and it is multilingual, available in English, Hindi and Punjabi. JobSphere technique uses 4-bit quantization, allowing the platform to deploy on consumer-grade GPUs (i.e., NVIDIA RTX 3050 4GB), making the implementation 89% cheaper than that of cloud-based systems. Key innovations include voice-enabled interaction with the assistant, automated mock tests, resume parsing with skills recognition, and embed-based job recommendation that achieves a precision@10 score of 68%. An evaluation of JobSphere's implementation reveals 94% factual accuracy, a median response time of 1.8 seconds, and a System Usability Scale score of 78.5/100, a 50% improvement compared to the baseline PGRKAM platform context. In conclusion, JobSphere effectively fills significant accessibility gaps for Punjab/Hindi-speaking users in rural locations, while also affirming the users access to trusted job content provided by government agencies.

item.title: AI-Powered Data Visualization Platform: An Intelligent Web Application for Automated Dataset Analysis
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: AI-powered, data visualization, automatic data cleaning, feature selection, cloud-based platform

Summary: This article presents an AI-powered data visualization platform that fully automates the data analysis workflow, starting from dataset upload to generating interactive visualizations. It incorporates advanced machine learning algorithms for data cleaning and preprocessing, including imputation of missing values and outlier detection, enhancing the accuracy and usability of datasets. The system intelligently selects features using four different algorithms and generates meaningful visualization titles based on dataset attributes, streamlining the analytical process. The platform is built with a Python Flask backend and React frontend, integrated with Firebase Cloud Storage to support real-time data processing and handle multiple user requests simultaneously, ensuring scalability. Performance evaluation was conducted on two separate datasets, including handling large datasets of up to 100,000 rows in real-time, demonstrating the system’s efficiency and robustness. The cloud-based approach significantly reduces manual intervention in the data analysis process while maintaining high-quality, impactful visual outputs. Overall, this platform establishes a new standard for automating AI-driven data analysis and visualization in data-driven environments, offering improved user experience and faster insights.
arXiv:2511.08363v2 Announce Type: replace Abstract: An AI-powered data visualization platform that automates the entire data analysis process, from uploading a dataset to generating an interactive visualization. Advanced machine learning algorithms are employed to clean and preprocess the data, analyse its features, and automatically select appropriate visualizations. The system establishes the process of automating AI-based analysis and visualization from the context of data-driven environments, and eliminates the challenge of time-consuming manual data analysis. The combination of a Python Flask backend to access the dataset, paired with a React frontend, provides a robust platform that automatically interacts with Firebase Cloud Storage for numerous data processing and data analysis solutions and real-time sources. Key contributions include automatic and intelligent data cleaning, with imputation for missing values, and detection of outliers, via analysis of the data set. AI solutions to intelligently select features, using four different algorithms, and intelligent title generation and visualization are determined by the attributes of the dataset. These contributions were evaluated using two separate datasets to assess the platform's performance. In the process evaluation, the initial analysis was performed in real-time on datasets as large as 100000 rows, while the cloud-based demand platform scales to meet requests from multiple users and processes them simultaneously. In conclusion, the cloud-based data visualization application allowed for a significant reduction of manual inputs to the data analysis process while maintaining a high quality, impactful visual outputs, and user experiences

item.title: Heterogeneous Graph Neural Networks for Assumption-Based Argumentation
item.content:encoded:
Assumption-Based Argumentation, Graph Neural Networks, Stable Semantics, Credulous Acceptance, Structured Argumentation

Summary: This paper addresses the computational challenge of exact extension calculation under stable semantics in Assumption-Based Argumentation (ABA), particularly for large frameworks where it becomes intractable. The authors introduce the first application of Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) to approximate credulous acceptance in ABA. They represent ABA frameworks using a dependency graph that encodes assumptions, claims, and rules as nodes, while utilizing heterogeneous edge labels to differentiate support, derive, and attack relations. Two novel GNN architectures are proposed: ABAGCN, which employs residual heterogeneous convolution layers, and ABAGAT, which uses residual heterogeneous attention layers for node embedding learning. The models are trained on the ICCMA 2023 benchmark dataset, supplemented with synthetic ABA frameworks, with hyperparameters optimized through Bayesian search. Experimentally, both ABAGCN and ABAGAT outperform an adapted state-of-the-art baseline from abstract argumentation, achieving node-level F1 scores up to 0.71 on ICCMA instances. Additionally, the authors design a polynomial-time extension-reconstruction algorithm informed by their predictors, capable of reconstructing stable extensions with F1 scores above 0.85 on small frameworks and around 0.58 on large ones. This work thus facilitates scalable approximate reasoning in structured argumentation, opening new directions for practical ABA applications.
arXiv:2511.08982v2 Announce Type: replace Abstract: Assumption-Based Argumentation (ABA) is a powerful structured argumentation formalism, but exact computation of extensions under stable semantics is intractable for large frameworks. We present the first Graph Neural Network (GNN) approach to approximate credulous acceptance in ABA. To leverage GNNs, we model ABA frameworks via a dependency graph representation encoding assumptions, claims and rules as nodes, with heterogeneous edge labels distinguishing support, derive and attack relations. We propose two GNN architectures - ABAGCN and ABAGAT - that stack residual heterogeneous convolution or attention layers, respectively, to learn node embeddings. Our models are trained on the ICCMA 2023 benchmark, augmented with synthetic ABAFs, with hyperparameters optimised via Bayesian search. Empirically, both ABAGCN and ABAGAT outperform a state-of-the-art GNN baseline that we adapt from the abstract argumentation literature, achieving a node-level F1 score of up to 0.71 on the ICCMA instances. Finally, we develop a sound polynomial time extension-reconstruction algorithm driven by our predictor: it reconstructs stable extensions with F1 above 0.85 on small ABAFs and maintains an F1 of about 0.58 on large frameworks. Our work opens new avenues for scalable approximate reasoning in structured argumentation.

item.title: HyperD: Hybrid Periodicity Decoupling Framework for Traffic Forecasting
item.content:encoded:
Traffic forecasting, spatial-temporal attention, periodic patterns, frequency domain, deep learning

Summary:

Accurate traffic forecasting is essential to intelligent transportation systems, aiding in congestion control, route planning, and urban mobility optimization. However, forecasting remains challenging due to complex spatial dependencies among road segments and traffic sensors, and the coexistence of multi-scale periodic patterns such as daily and weekly human routines alongside irregular fluctuations caused by unpredictable events like accidents or weather. To address these challenges, the paper proposes HyperD (Hybrid Periodic Decoupling), a novel framework that separates traffic data into periodic and residual components. The periodic component is managed by the Hybrid Periodic Representation Module, which captures fine-grained daily and weekly patterns through learnable periodic embeddings combined with spatial-temporal attention mechanisms. The residual component, representing non-periodic high-frequency fluctuations, is modeled via the Frequency-Aware Residual Representation Module, which utilizes complex-valued multilayer perceptrons operating in the frequency domain. To ensure effective separation and representation, a Dual-View Alignment Loss aligns low-frequency information with the periodic branch and high-frequency information with the residual branch. Extensive experiments on four real-world datasets demonstrate that HyperD achieves state-of-the-art prediction accuracy, improved robustness against disturbances, and better computational efficiency compared to existing methods.
arXiv:2511.09275v2 Announce Type: replace Abstract: Accurate traffic forecasting plays a vital role in intelligent transportation systems, enabling applications such as congestion control, route planning, and urban mobility optimization. However, traffic forecasting remains challenging due to two key factors: (1) complex spatial dependencies arising from dynamic interactions between road segments and traffic sensors across the network, and (2) the coexistence of multi-scale periodic patterns (e.g., daily and weekly periodic patterns driven by human routines) with irregular fluctuations caused by unpredictable events (e.g., accidents, weather, or construction). To tackle these challenges, we propose HyperD (Hybrid Periodic Decoupling), a novel framework that decouples traffic data into periodic and residual components. The periodic component is handled by the Hybrid Periodic Representation Module, which extracts fine-grained daily and weekly patterns using learnable periodic embeddings and spatial-temporal attention. The residual component, which captures non-periodic, high-frequency fluctuations, is modeled by the Frequency-Aware Residual Representation Module, leveraging complex-valued MLP in frequency domain. To enforce semantic separation between the two components, we further introduce a Dual-View Alignment Loss, which aligns low-frequency information with the periodic branch and high-frequency information with the residual branch. Extensive experiments on four real-world traffic datasets demonstrate that HyperD achieves state-of-the-art prediction accuracy, while offering superior robustness under disturbances and improved computational efficiency compared to existing methods.

item.title: From Model Training to Model Raising
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: AI alignment, model raising, training corpus, value systems, social interactions

Summary: The paper critiques current AI training methodologies that align models with human values only after establishing the model's core capabilities, which often results in fragile alignment and superficial value integration. It proposes a new paradigm called "model raising," where alignment is integrated from the very beginning of a model's development. Central to this approach is a fundamental redesign of the training corpus, emphasizing reframing data from a first-person perspective to foster a deeper connection between the model and the information. This approach also calls for recontextualizing training data as lived experience, making it more akin to human learning processes. Additionally, the paradigm encourages simulating social interactions within the training data to build contextual awareness and social value understanding. Another key component is scaffolding the ordering of the training data to gradually develop and reinforce values throughout the training process. By embedding values deeply from the very first training token onward, knowledge, skills, and ethics are intrinsically linked, making them much harder to dissociate later. This is especially critical as large language models begin to surpass human capabilities in various tasks, making early value integration essential for safe and reliable AI development.
arXiv:2511.09287v2 Announce Type: replace Abstract: Current AI training methods align models with human values only after their core capabilities have been established, resulting in models that are easily misaligned and lack deep-rooted value systems. We propose a paradigm shift from "model training" to "model raising", in which alignment is woven into a model's development from the start. We identify several key components for this paradigm, all centered around redesigning the training corpus: reframing training data from a first-person perspective, recontextualizing information as lived experience, simulating social interactions, and scaffolding the ordering of training data. We expect that this redesign of the training corpus will lead to an early commitment to values from the first training token onward, such that knowledge, skills, and values are intrinsically much harder to separate. In an ecosystem in which large language model capabilities start overtaking human capabilities in many tasks, this seems to us like a critical need.

item.title: Global Convergence of Policy Gradient for Entropy Regularized Linear-Quadratic Control with Multiplicative Noise
item.content:encoded:
Reinforcement Learning, Entropy Regularization, Linear Quadratic Control, Policy Gradient, Zero-Order Optimization

Summary:

This paper explores reinforcement learning (RL) methods for controlling entropy-regularized Linear Quadratic Control (LQC) problems with multiplicative noise over an infinite time horizon, focusing on scenarios where system parameters are unknown. First, the authors adapt the Regularized Policy Gradient (RPG) algorithm to stochastic optimal control frameworks, establishing that despite the inherent non-convexity, RPG achieves global convergence under conditions of gradient domination and near-smoothness. Second, they propose a novel model-free RL algorithm called Sample-Based Regularized Policy Gradient (SB-RPG), which relies on zero-order optimization techniques and operates without requiring knowledge of system parameters. The use of entropy regularization within the model serves to accelerate convergence and effectively balance the exploration-exploitation trade-off fundamental to RL problems. Finally, numerical simulations are conducted, confirming the theoretical convergence guarantees and demonstrating the practical effectiveness of the SB-RPG algorithm in environments with unknown system parameters. This work contributes a theoretically grounded and computationally feasible methodology for RL in complex stochastic control settings, emphasizing global convergence and robust performance without model knowledge.
arXiv:2510.02896v3 Announce Type: replace-cross Abstract: Reinforcement Learning (RL) has emerged as a powerful framework for sequential decision-making in dynamic environments, particularly when system parameters are unknown. This paper investigates RL-based control for entropy-regularized Linear Quadratic control (LQC) problems with multiplicative noises over an infinite time horizon. First, we adapt the Regularized Policy Gradient (RPG) algorithm to stochastic optimal control settings, proving that despite the non-convexity of the problem, RPG converges globally under conditions of gradient domination and near-smoothness. Second, based on zero-order optimization approach, we introduce a novel model free RL algorithm: Sample-Based Regularized Policy Gradient (SB-RPG). SB-RPG operates without knowledge of system parameters yet still retains strong theoretical guarantees of global convergence. Our model leverages entropy regularization to accelerate convergence and address the exploration versus exploitation trade-off inherent in RL. Numerical simulations validate the theoretical results and demonstrate the efficacy of SB-RPG in unknown-parameters environments.

item.title: Test-driven Reinforcement Learning
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: reinforcement learning, reward design, test-driven learning, policy optimization, DeepMind Control Suite

Summary:

1. This paper addresses the challenge of manually designing reward functions in reinforcement learning (RL), which often leads to suboptimal task representations since rewards must both define objectives and guide learning.

2. Inspired by satisficing theory, the authors propose a Test-driven Reinforcement Learning (TdRL) framework that replaces a single reward function with multiple test functions to represent task objectives. These tests are categorized into pass-fail tests to define optimal objectives and indicative tests to guide learning.

3. The authors theoretically prove that if a trajectory return function assigns higher returns to trajectories closer to the optimal set, then maximum entropy policy optimization based on this function yields policies closer to optimal policies.

4. A lexicographic heuristic is introduced to compare how close trajectories are relative to the optimal trajectory set, aiding in learning the trajectory return function effectively.

5. An algorithm implementation of TdRL is developed and evaluated on the DeepMind Control Suite benchmark, showing that TdRL matches or outperforms handcrafted reward methods while offering simpler task design and built-in support for multi-objective optimization. The framework provides a fresh perspective on defining task objectives to overcome reward design difficulties in RL applications.
arXiv:2511.07904v2 Announce Type: replace-cross Abstract: Reinforcement learning (RL) has been recognized as a powerful tool for robot control tasks. RL typically employs reward functions to define task objectives and guide agent learning. However, since the reward function serves the dual purpose of defining the optimal goal and guiding learning, it is challenging to design the reward function manually, which often results in a suboptimal task representation. To tackle the reward design challenge in RL, inspired by the satisficing theory, we propose a Test-driven Reinforcement Learning (TdRL) framework. In the TdRL framework, multiple test functions are used to represent the task objective rather than a single reward function. Test functions can be categorized as pass-fail tests and indicative tests, each dedicated to defining the optimal objective and guiding the learning process, respectively, thereby making defining tasks easier. Building upon such a task definition, we first prove that if a trajectory return function assigns higher returns to trajectories closer to the optimal trajectory set, maximum entropy policy optimization based on this return function will yield a policy that is closer to the optimal policy set. Then, we introduce a lexicographic heuristic approach to compare the relative distance relationship between trajectories and the optimal trajectory set for learning the trajectory return function. Furthermore, we develop an algorithm implementation of TdRL. Experimental results on the DeepMind Control Suite benchmark demonstrate that TdRL matches or outperforms handcrafted reward methods in policy training, with greater design simplicity and inherent support for multi-objective optimization. We argue that TdRL offers a novel perspective for representing task objectives, which could be helpful in addressing the reward design challenges in RL applications.

item.title: Self-Correction Distillation for Structured Data Question Answering
item.content:encoded:
Structured data QA, small-scale LLMs, self-correction distillation, error prompt mechanism, two-stage distillation

Summary:

1. The paper addresses structured data question answering (QA) across multiple formats, including table QA, Knowledge Graph (KG) QA, and temporal KG QA, acknowledging its significance in advancing natural language understanding.
2. It highlights the limitations of current unified structural QA frameworks like TrustUQA, especially when employed with small-scale large language models (LLMs), due to higher error rates in generating structured queries.
3. To overcome these challenges, the authors propose a Self-Correction Distillation (SCD) method that incorporates an Error Prompt Mechanism (EPM) for real-time error detection and customized error messages during inference.
4. The SCD utilizes a two-stage distillation strategy designed to impart the query-generation and error-correction capabilities from large-scale LLMs to smaller 8B parameter models.
5. Experimental results across five benchmarks involving three different structured data types demonstrate that SCD not only outperforms other distillation methods on small-scale LLMs but also approaches GPT-4 level performance on some datasets, while large-scale LLMs equipped with EPM achieve state-of-the-art results on most datasets.
arXiv:2511.07998v2 Announce Type: replace-cross Abstract: Structured data question answering (QA), including table QA, Knowledge Graph (KG) QA, and temporal KG QA, is a pivotal research area. Advances in large language models (LLMs) have driven significant progress in unified structural QA frameworks like TrustUQA. However, these frameworks face challenges when applied to small-scale LLMs since small-scale LLMs are prone to errors in generating structured queries. To improve the structured data QA ability of small-scale LLMs, we propose a self-correction distillation (SCD) method. In SCD, an error prompt mechanism (EPM) is designed to detect errors and provide customized error messages during inference, and a two-stage distillation strategy is designed to transfer large-scale LLMs' query-generation and error-correction capabilities to small-scale LLM. Experiments across 5 benchmarks with 3 structured data types demonstrate that our SCD achieves the best performance and superior generalization on small-scale LLM (8B) compared to other distillation methods, and closely approaches the performance of GPT4 on some datasets. Furthermore, large-scale LLMs equipped with EPM surpass the state-of-the-art results on most datasets.

item.title: Constrained and Robust Policy Synthesis with Satisfiability-Modulo-Probabilistic-Model-Checking
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: robust policies, Markov decision processes, structural constraints, satisfiability solvers, probabilistic model checking

Summary:

This paper addresses the challenge of computing reward-optimal policies for finite Markov decision processes (MDPs) that are robust to perturbations and satisfy additional structural constraints. First, the authors identify the need for policies that not only optimize rewards but are also resilient to changes in the MDP environment and adhere to limits related to policy representation or implementation costs. Second, they introduce a novel and flexible framework that enables expressing these structural constraints within a first-order theory over sets of MDPs. Third, the approach integrates satisfiability solvers tightly with probabilistic model checking algorithms, combining the strengths of logical reasoning and quantitative verification to tackle the combinatorial complexity of robust constrained policy synthesis efficiently. Fourth, the methodology is evaluated on several hundred benchmark problems, showcasing its practical feasibility in synthesizing robust and constrained policies. Lastly, experimental results highlight competitiveness with existing state-of-the-art techniques across various problem fragments, demonstrating the framework's effectiveness and scalability for complex policy synthesis tasks in planning, controller synthesis, and verification contexts.
arXiv:2511.08078v2 Announce Type: replace-cross Abstract: The ability to compute reward-optimal policies for given and known finite Markov decision processes (MDPs) underpins a variety of applications across planning, controller synthesis, and verification. However, we often want policies (1) to be robust, i.e., they perform well on perturbations of the MDP and (2) to satisfy additional structural constraints regarding, e.g., their representation or implementation cost. Computing such robust and constrained policies is indeed computationally more challenging. This paper contributes the first approach to effectively compute robust policies subject to arbitrary structural constraints using a flexible and efficient framework. We achieve flexibility by allowing to express our constraints in a first-order theory over a set of MDPs, while the root for our efficiency lies in the tight integration of satisfiability solvers to handle the combinatorial nature of the problem and probabilistic model checking algorithms to handle the analysis of MDPs. Experiments on a few hundred benchmarks demonstrate the feasibility for constrained and robust policy synthesis and the competitiveness with state-of-the-art methods for various fragments of the problem.

item.title: MARC: Multimodal and Multi-Task Agentic Retrieval-Augmented Generation for Cold-Start Recommender System
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: recommender systems, cold-start, Large Language Models, graph database, Agentic Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG)

Summary: 1. The paper addresses challenges faced by recommender systems (RS) during cold-start conditions by leveraging multimodal data and agent concepts empowered by Large Language Models (LLMs). 2. It focuses on the food and beverage domain, where traditional recommendation approaches rely heavily on knowledge graphs and ontology due to unique data attributes and intricate relationships. 3. The authors introduce MARC, a multimodal and multi-task cocktail recommender system that uses Agentic Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) and a graph database to improve recommendations under cold-start scenarios. 4. MARC operates via two key components: a task recognition router that directs queries appropriately and a reflection process that enhances answer quality by iteratively reasoning over the data. 5. The core graph database was built from cocktail datasets sourced from Kaggle and evaluated on 200 manually crafted questions. 6. Evaluation methodologies included both LLM-based judgment and human assessment, confirming that responses generated by querying the custom graph database significantly outperformed those from a simpler vector-based retrieval system in answer quality. 7. The research highlights the effectiveness of integrating graph databases with LLM-driven agentic retrieval to produce contextually appropriate and high-quality recommendations. 8. The codebase for the MARC system is publicly available at the provided GitHub repository for reproducibility and further exploration.
arXiv:2511.08181v2 Announce Type: replace-cross Abstract: Recommender systems (RS) are currently being studied to mitigate limitations during cold-start conditions by leveraging modality information or introducing Agent concepts based on the exceptional reasoning capabilities of Large Language Models (LLMs). Meanwhile, food and beverage recommender systems have traditionally used knowledge graph and ontology concepts due to the domain's unique data attributes and relationship characteristics. On this background, we propose MARC, a multimodal and multi-task cocktail recommender system based on Agentic Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) utilizing graph database under cold-start conditions. The proposed system generates high-quality, contextually appropriate answers through two core processes: a task recognition router and a reflection process. The graph database was constructed by processing cocktail data from Kaggle, and its effectiveness was evaluated using 200 manually crafted questions. The evaluation used both LLM-as-a-judge and human evaluation to demonstrate that answers generated via the graph database outperformed those from a simple vector database in terms of quality. The code is available at https://github.com/diddbwls/cocktail_rec_agentrag

item.title: HQ-SVC: Towards High-Quality Zero-Shot Singing Voice Conversion in Low-Resource Scenarios
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: zero-shot singing voice conversion, decoupled codec, pitch and volume modeling, differentiable signal processing, diffusion techniques

Summary: This paper introduces HQ-SVC, a novel and efficient framework designed for high-quality zero-shot singing voice conversion (SVC). Unlike previous methods that separately model speaker timbre and vocal content, leading to loss of critical acoustic information and increased computational demand, HQ-SVC jointly extracts content and speaker features through a decoupled codec. The framework further enhances audio fidelity by incorporating pitch and volume modeling, thereby preserving acoustic cues often lost in traditional separate modeling approaches. Moreover, HQ-SVC progressively refines the converted outputs using differentiable signal processing and diffusion techniques, contributing to improved output quality. Evaluations demonstrate that HQ-SVC significantly outperforms existing state-of-the-art zero-shot SVC methods in both conversion quality and computational efficiency. Additionally, HQ-SVC shows superior voice naturalness compared to specialized audio super-resolution techniques. It also natively supports voice super-resolution tasks, highlighting its versatility beyond singing voice conversion. This work presents a substantial advancement in SVC technology by improving both the quality and efficiency of voice conversion while preserving important acoustic characteristics.
arXiv:2511.08496v3 Announce Type: replace-cross Abstract: Zero-shot singing voice conversion (SVC) transforms a source singer's timbre to an unseen target speaker's voice while preserving melodic content without fine-tuning. Existing methods model speaker timbre and vocal content separately, losing essential acoustic information that degrades output quality while requiring significant computational resources. To overcome these limitations, we propose HQ-SVC, an efficient framework for high-quality zero-shot SVC. HQ-SVC first extracts jointly content and speaker features using a decoupled codec. It then enhances fidelity through pitch and volume modeling, preserving critical acoustic information typically lost in separate modeling approaches, and progressively refines outputs via differentiable signal processing and diffusion techniques. Evaluations confirm HQ-SVC significantly outperforms state-of-the-art zero-shot SVC methods in conversion quality and efficiency. Beyond voice conversion, HQ-SVC achieves superior voice naturalness compared to specialized audio super-resolution methods while natively supporting voice super-resolution tasks.

item.title: PAN: A World Model for General, Interactable, and Long-Horizon World Simulation
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: world model, video simulation, Generative Latent Prediction, large language model, long-horizon forecasting

Summary:

This paper introduces PAN, a generalizable and interactive world model designed for long-horizon prediction of future states through high-quality video simulation. Unlike typical video generation models that create videos from prompts without causal control or long-term consistency, PAN enables action-conditioned simulation allowing purposeful reasoning and planning. PAN leverages the Generative Latent Prediction (GLP) architecture, which integrates an autoregressive latent dynamics backbone powered by a large language model (LLM) to ground simulations in text-based knowledge and support conditioning on natural language actions. The visual component is addressed by a video diffusion decoder that reconstructs detailed and temporally coherent frames, effectively bridging latent imagination with perceptible reality. Trained on extensive video-action datasets covering diverse domains, PAN exhibits strong capabilities in open-domain simulation, maintaining coherent dynamics over long time scales. Empirical evaluations demonstrate PAN’s superior performance in action-conditioned world modeling, long-horizon forecasting, and simulative reasoning compared to existing video generators and world models. This work marks progress toward general-purpose world models that support predictive simulation for reasoning and acting across varied environments and interaction formats.
arXiv:2511.09057v3 Announce Type: replace-cross Abstract: A world model enables an intelligent agent to imagine, predict, and reason about how the world evolves in response to its actions, and accordingly to plan and strategize. While recent video generation models produce realistic visual sequences, they typically operate in the prompt-to-full-video manner without causal control, interactivity, or long-horizon consistency required for purposeful reasoning. Existing world modeling efforts, on the other hand, often focus on restricted domains (e.g., physical, game, or 3D-scene dynamics) with limited depth and controllability, and struggle to generalize across diverse environments and interaction formats. In this work, we introduce PAN, a general, interactable, and long-horizon world model that predicts future world states through high-quality video simulation conditioned on history and natural language actions. PAN employs the Generative Latent Prediction (GLP) architecture that combines an autoregressive latent dynamics backbone based on a large language model (LLM), which grounds simulation in extensive text-based knowledge and enables conditioning on language-specified actions, with a video diffusion decoder that reconstructs perceptually detailed and temporally coherent visual observations, to achieve a unification between latent space reasoning (imagination) and realizable world dynamics (reality). Trained on large-scale video-action pairs spanning diverse domains, PAN supports open-domain, action-conditioned simulation with coherent, long-term dynamics. Extensive experiments show that PAN achieves strong performance in action-conditioned world simulation, long-horizon forecasting, and simulative reasoning compared to other video generators and world models, taking a step towards general world models that enable predictive simulation of future world states for reasoning and acting.

item.title: Good-for-MDP State Reduction for Stochastic LTL Planning
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Markov Decision Processes, Linear Temporal Logic, Good-for-MDP automata, state-space reduction, co-safety formulas

Summary:

This paper addresses stochastic planning problems modeled by Markov Decision Processes (MDPs) with goals expressed in Linear Temporal Logic (LTL). The current leading method converts LTL formulas into good-for-MDP (GFM) automata, which limit nondeterminism, allowing it to be resolved during policy synthesis with MDPs. A critical challenge for scalability is the large size of these automata. The authors propose a novel state-space reduction technique specifically for GFM automata, which drastically decreases the number of states. Their approach uses a sequence of advanced transformations inspired by recent developments in good-for-games minimization from adversarial settings. Beyond theoretical advancements, the paper provides empirical results that showcase the effectiveness of the proposed reduction method in practice. Additionally, the authors introduce a direct construction method for a special class of LTL formulas of the form 𝔾𝔽φ, where φ is a co-safety formula, achieving a single-exponential worst-case complexity. This contrasts favorably with the general doubly-exponential complexity known for such problems. Experimental results further confirm the practical scalability benefits of this specialized construction for stochastic planning with temporal logic goals.
arXiv:2511.09073v2 Announce Type: replace-cross Abstract: We study stochastic planning problems in Markov Decision Processes (MDPs) with goals specified in Linear Temporal Logic (LTL). The state-of-the-art approach transforms LTL formulas into good-for-MDP (GFM) automata, which feature a restricted form of nondeterminism. These automata are then composed with the MDP, allowing the agent to resolve the nondeterminism during policy synthesis. A major factor affecting the scalability of this approach is the size of the generated automata. In this paper, we propose a novel GFM state-space reduction technique that significantly reduces the number of automata states. Our method employs a sophisticated chain of transformations, leveraging recent advances in good-for-games minimisation developed for adversarial settings. In addition to our theoretical contributions, we present empirical results demonstrating the practical effectiveness of our state-reduction technique. Furthermore, we introduce a direct construction method for formulas of the form $\mathsf{G}\mathsf{F}\varphi$, where $\varphi$ is a co-safety formula. This construction is provably single-exponential in the worst case, in contrast to the general doubly-exponential complexity. Our experiments confirm the scalability advantages of this specialised construction.

item.title: C$^3$TG: Conflict-aware, Composite, and Collaborative Controlled Text Generation
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: large language models, multi-attribute control, controlled text generation, iterative optimization, conflict resolution

Summary:

Recent advancements in large language models (LLMs) showcase impressive text generation, yet controlling multiple text attributes simultaneously remains a challenge without major architectural changes or fine-tuning. Existing approaches typically manage only one basic attribute at a time and lack mechanisms to handle conflicts when multiple attribute requirements clash, often causing interference. Moreover, current methods do not incorporate iterative optimization in the controlled generation process, limiting precision. To overcome these challenges, the proposed Conflict-aware, Composite, and Collaborative Controlled Text Generation (C³TG) framework introduces a two-phase method for fine-grained multi-dimensional attribute control. During generation, C³TG pairs an LLM with selected classifiers from 17 attribute dimensions and uses weighted KL-divergence to adjust token probabilities accordingly. In the optimization phase, it applies an energy function combining classifier scores and penalty terms to resolve attribute conflicts iteratively, ensuring accurate multi-attribute control while maintaining natural language flow. Experimental results demonstrate that C³TG outperforms baselines significantly across attribute accuracy, linguistic fluency, and output diversity, while also reducing toxicity. This establishes C³TG as a flexible, effective solution for multi-dimensional controlled text generation that does not require costly model modifications.
arXiv:2511.09292v2 Announce Type: replace-cross Abstract: Recent advancements in large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable text generation capabilities. However, controlling specific attributes of generated text remains challenging without architectural modifications or extensive fine-tuning. Current methods typically toggle a single, basic attribute but struggle with precise multi-attribute control. In scenarios where attribute requirements conflict, existing methods lack coordination mechanisms, causing interference between desired attributes. Furthermore, these methods fail to incorporate iterative optimization processes in the controlled generation pipeline. To address these limitations, we propose Conflict-aware, Composite, and Collaborative Controlled Text Generation (C$^3$TG), a two-phase framework for fine-grained, multi-dimensional text attribute control. During generation, C$^3$TG selectively pairs the LLM with the required attribute classifiers from the 17 available dimensions and employs weighted KL-divergence to adjust token probabilities. The optimization phase then leverages an energy function combining classifier scores and penalty terms to resolve attribute conflicts through iterative feedback, enabling precise control over multiple dimensions simultaneously while preserving natural text flow. Experiments show that C$^3$TG significantly outperforms baselines across multiple metrics including attribute accuracy, linguistic fluency, and output diversity, while simultaneously reducing toxicity. These results establish C$^3$TG as an effective and flexible solution for multi-dimensional text attribute control that requires no costly model modifications.

item.title: LLM-Generated Negative News Headlines Dataset: Creation and Benchmarking Against Real Journalism
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Large Language Models, synthetic data, negative valence text, sentiment analysis, news headlines

Summary:

This study investigates the use of datasets generated by Large Language Models (LLMs) to support Natural Language Processing (NLP) tasks, addressing difficulties related to acquiring real-world data and privacy issues. It focuses on negative valence text, which is crucial for sentiment analysis, by generating synthetic negative news headlines through carefully designed prompts to cover a wide range of negative sentiments across different societal domains. The created synthetic corpus was subjected to expert review for validation and analyzed in embedding space to compare its alignment with authentic negative news headlines concerning content, tone, length, and style. Various performance metrics such as correlation with real headlines, perplexity, coherence, and realism were evaluated. The synthetic dataset underwent benchmarking against two real headline datasets using multiple tests including Comparative Perplexity Test, Comparative Readability Test, Comparative Part-Of-Speech (POS) Profiling, BERTScore, and Comparative Semantic Similarity. The results demonstrate that the generated headlines closely resemble real ones, with the principal difference being a variation in the proper noun score identified in the POS profile test, underscoring the synthetic data’s viability as an alternative resource for sentiment analysis in NLP.
arXiv:2511.11591v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: This research examines the potential of datasets generated by Large Language Models (LLMs) to support Natural Language Processing (NLP) tasks, aiming to overcome challenges related to data acquisition and privacy concerns associated with real-world data. Focusing on negative valence text, a critical component of sentiment analysis, we explore the use of LLM-generated synthetic news headlines as an alternative to real-world data. A specialized corpus of negative news headlines was created using tailored prompts to capture diverse negative sentiments across various societal domains. The synthetic headlines were validated by expert review and further analyzed in embedding space to assess their alignment with real-world negative news in terms of content, tone, length, and style. Key metrics such as correlation with real headlines, perplexity, coherence, and realism were evaluated. The synthetic dataset was benchmarked against two sets of real news headlines using evaluations including the Comparative Perplexity Test, Comparative Readability Test, Comparative POS Profiling, BERTScore, and Comparative Semantic Similarity. Results show the generated headlines match real headlines with the only marked divergence being in the proper noun score of the POS profile test.

item.title: CLINB: A Climate Intelligence Benchmark for Foundational Models
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Large Language Models, Climate Change, Multimodal QA, Knowledge Synthesis, Hallucination

Summary: This paper introduces CLINB, a novel benchmark designed to evaluate Large Language Models (LLMs) on complex, specialized tasks related to climate change. The benchmark features open-ended, grounded, and multimodal question answering challenges that require high-quality knowledge and evidence-based responses. CLINB is built using real user questions and evaluation rubrics curated by leading climate scientists, ensuring domain relevance and rigor. The authors implement a model-based evaluation methodology to assess several state-of-the-art models against this benchmark. Results reveal a striking dichotomy: while frontier LLMs demonstrate exceptional capabilities in synthesizing knowledge, often at a PhD-level understanding and presentation quality, they struggle with grounding their answers properly. In particular, high rates of hallucinated references and images are observed, undermining the reliability of the evidence presented. Compared with hybrid answers created by experts aided by weaker models, these advanced models perform better in knowledge synthesis but worse in verifiable attribution. The study underscores the necessity of bridging the gap between knowledge synthesis and evidence grounding to deploy AI safely and effectively in scientific workflows. Finally, the paper argues for the importance of relying on interpretable and trustworthy benchmarks like CLINB to accelerate the development of credible AI systems in specialized domains.
arXiv:2511.11597v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Evaluating how Large Language Models (LLMs) handle complex, specialized knowledge remains a critical challenge. We address this through the lens of climate change by introducing CLINB, a benchmark that assesses models on open-ended, grounded, multimodal question answering tasks with clear requirements for knowledge quality and evidential support. CLINB relies on a dataset of real users' questions and evaluation rubrics curated by leading climate scientists. We implement and validate a model-based evaluation process and evaluate several frontier models. Our findings reveal a critical dichotomy. Frontier models demonstrate remarkable knowledge synthesis capabilities, often exhibiting PhD-level understanding and presentation quality. They outperform "hybrid" answers curated by domain experts assisted by weaker models. However, this performance is countered by failures in grounding. The quality of evidence varies, with substantial hallucination rates for references and images. We argue that bridging this gap between knowledge synthesis and verifiable attribution is essential for the deployment of AI in scientific workflows and that reliable, interpretable benchmarks like CLINB are needed to progress towards building trustworthy AI systems.

item.title: SynBullying: A Multi LLM Synthetic Conversational Dataset for Cyberbullying Detectio
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: SynBullying, cyberbullying detection, multi-LLM dataset, conversational context, fine-grained labeling

Summary: The paper presents SynBullying, a synthetic conversational dataset designed for studying and detecting cyberbullying (CB) using large language models (LLMs). Unlike traditional datasets based on isolated posts, SynBullying captures multi-turn conversational exchanges to better reflect real-life interactions. The dataset includes context-aware annotations that evaluate harmfulness by considering conversational flow, intent, and discourse dynamics, thereby providing more nuanced understanding of bullying behavior. Additionally, it offers fine-grained labeling across several CB categories to facilitate detailed linguistic and behavioral analyses. The authors evaluate SynBullying on five main dimensions: conversational structure, lexical patterns, sentiment and toxicity levels, role dynamics within conversations, harm intensity, and distribution of cyberbullying types. To demonstrate its practical value, the dataset is tested both as standalone training data for cyberbullying classifiers and as additional augmentation data to improve existing models. Results indicate that SynBullying is a scalable, ethically safer alternative to human data collection and can enhance CB detection capabilities by providing rich, context-aware, and multi-dimensional data. This work marks a significant step toward better understanding and addressing cyberbullying through synthetic data generation driven by advances in LLMs.
arXiv:2511.11599v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We introduce SynBullying, a synthetic multi-LLM conversational dataset for studying and detecting cyberbullying (CB). SynBullying provides a scalable and ethically safe alternative to human data collection by leveraging large language models (LLMs) to simulate realistic bullying interactions. The dataset offers (i) conversational structure, capturing multi-turn exchanges rather than isolated posts; (ii) context-aware annotations, where harmfulness is assessed within the conversational flow considering context, intent, and discourse dynamics; and (iii) fine-grained labeling, covering various CB categories for detailed linguistic and behavioral analysis. We evaluate SynBullying across five dimensions, including conversational structure, lexical patterns, sentiment/toxicity, role dynamics, harm intensity, and CB-type distribution. We further examine its utility by testing its performance as standalone training data and as an augmentation source for CB classification.

item.title: CausalGuard: A Smart System for Detecting and Preventing False Information in Large Language Models
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: hallucination, large language models, causal reasoning, symbolic logic, automated reasoning

Summary: The paper addresses a critical problem in large language models (LLMs): hallucination, where models confidently produce false but plausible information. This issue limits their use in high-stakes applications demanding accuracy. Existing solutions face challenges such as requiring full model retraining, introducing high computational costs, or failing to target the root cause of hallucinations. The authors introduce CausalGuard, a novel method that combines causal reasoning with symbolic logic to detect and prevent hallucinations in real time rather than post-generation. CausalGuard employs two complementary approaches: tracing causal chains from model knowledge to generated outputs, and verifying logical consistency via automated reasoning techniques. Evaluation across twelve benchmarks shows CausalGuard identifies hallucinations with 89.3% accuracy, missing only 8.3% of cases, and reduces false claims by nearly 80%, all while maintaining natural and helpful responses. The system excels in complex multi-step reasoning tasks. Additionally, CausalGuard’s transparency in revealing its reasoning steps makes it particularly suitable for sensitive domains such as medical diagnosis and financial analysis, where understanding the rationale behind decisions is as important as the decisions themselves.
arXiv:2511.11600v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: While large language models have transformed how we interact with AI systems, they have a critical weakness: they confidently state false information that sounds entirely plausible. This "hallucination" problem has become a major barrier to using these models where accuracy matters most. Existing solutions either require retraining the entire model, add significant computational costs, or miss the root causes of why these hallucinations occur in the first place. We present CausalGuard, a new approach that combines causal reasoning with symbolic logic to catch and prevent hallucinations as they happen. Unlike previous methods that only check outputs after generation, our system understands the causal chain that leads to false statements and intervenes early in the process. CausalGuard works through two complementary paths: one that traces causal relationships between what the model knows and what it generates, and another that checks logical consistency using automated reasoning. Testing across twelve different benchmarks, we found that CausalGuard correctly identifies hallucinations 89.3\% of the time while missing only 8.3\% of actual hallucinations. More importantly, it reduces false claims by nearly 80\% while keeping responses natural and helpful. The system performs especially well on complex reasoning tasks where multiple steps of logic are required. Because CausalGuard shows its reasoning process, it works well in sensitive areas like medical diagnosis or financial analysis where understanding why a decision was made matters as much as the decision itself.

item.title: Quantifying Skill and Chance: A Unified Framework for the Geometry of Games
item.content:encoded:
Skill-Luck Index, stochastic decision trees, game balance, skill leverage, volatility

Summary:

This article introduces a novel quantitative framework designed to differentiate between skill and chance in games by conceptualizing games as stochastic decision trees influenced by two complementary control sources: skill and luck. The authors define the Skill-Luck Index S(G), which ranges from -1 to 1, by decomposing game outcomes into two components: skill leverage (K) and luck leverage (L). They apply this framework to a diverse set of 30 games, showcasing a spectrum from pure chance (e.g., coin toss with S = -1) to mixed games like backgammon (S = 0, Sigma = 1.20), and pure skill games such as chess (S = +1, Sigma = 0). Poker is highlighted as an example with moderate skill dominance (S = 0.33) and specific metrics (K = 0.40 ± 0.03, Sigma = 0.80). Additionally, the concept of volatility (Sigma) is introduced to measure uncertainty in outcomes over successive turns. The framework’s flexibility allows it to be generalized beyond games, applying to stochastic decision systems in general. Practical applications include enabling principled comparisons of player influence, assessing game balance, and evaluating predictive stability. This has significant implications for game design, AI evaluation, and broader risk assessment contexts.
arXiv:2511.11611v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We introduce a quantitative framework for separating skill and chance in games by modeling them as complementary sources of control over stochastic decision trees. We define the Skill-Luck Index S(G) in [-1, 1] by decomposing game outcomes into skill leverage K and luck leverage L. Applying this to 30 games reveals a continuum from pure chance (coin toss, S = -1) through mixed domains such as backgammon (S = 0, Sigma = 1.20) to pure skill (chess, S = +1, Sigma = 0). Poker exhibits moderate skill dominance (S = 0.33) with K = 0.40 +/- 0.03 and Sigma = 0.80. We further introduce volatility Sigma to quantify outcome uncertainty over successive turns. The framework extends to general stochastic decision systems, enabling principled comparisons of player influence, game balance, and predictive stability, with applications to game design, AI evaluation, and risk assessment.

item.title: Value-Aligned Prompt Moderation via Zero-Shot Agentic Rewriting for Safe Image Generation
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Generative vision-language models, safety, value alignment, prompt rewriting, text-to-image generation

Summary: Generative vision-language models like Stable Diffusion excel in creative media synthesis but risk producing unsafe, offensive, or culturally inappropriate content, especially under adversarial prompts. Existing defense mechanisms often struggle to maintain generation quality while ensuring alignment with human values and can be costly to implement. To overcome these issues, the paper introduces VALOR (Value-Aligned LLM-Overseen Rewriter), a modular, zero-shot framework that enhances safety and helpfulness in text-to-image generation. VALOR employs layered prompt analysis combined with human-aligned value reasoning. It includes a multi-level NSFW detector for lexical and semantic risk filtering, a cultural value alignment module that checks for social norm violations, legality issues, and representational ethics, and an intention disambiguator to identify subtle or indirect unsafe implications. When unsafe content is detected, prompts are selectively rewritten by a large language model guided by dynamic, role-specific instructions, aiming to preserve user intent while enforcing safety alignment. If the generated image still fails safety checks, VALOR can perform a stylistic regeneration to steer the output toward a safer visual domain without changing core semantics. Experiments show VALOR can reduce unsafe outputs by up to 100% while maintaining prompt usefulness and creativity, proving its scalability and effectiveness for safe and aligned image generation in open settings.
arXiv:2511.11693v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Generative vision-language models like Stable Diffusion demonstrate remarkable capabilities in creative media synthesis, but they also pose substantial risks of producing unsafe, offensive, or culturally inappropriate content when prompted adversarially. Current defenses struggle to align outputs with human values without sacrificing generation quality or incurring high costs. To address these challenges, we introduce VALOR (Value-Aligned LLM-Overseen Rewriter), a modular, zero-shot agentic framework for safer and more helpful text-to-image generation. VALOR integrates layered prompt analysis with human-aligned value reasoning: a multi-level NSFW detector filters lexical and semantic risks; a cultural value alignment module identifies violations of social norms, legality, and representational ethics; and an intention disambiguator detects subtle or indirect unsafe implications. When unsafe content is detected, prompts are selectively rewritten by a large language model under dynamic, role-specific instructions designed to preserve user intent while enforcing alignment. If the generated image still fails a safety check, VALOR optionally performs a stylistic regeneration to steer the output toward a safer visual domain without altering core semantics. Experiments across adversarial, ambiguous, and value-sensitive prompts show that VALOR significantly reduces unsafe outputs by up to 100.00% while preserving prompt usefulness and creativity. These results highlight VALOR as a scalable and effective approach for deploying safe, aligned, and helpful image generation systems in open-world settings.

item.title: Towards autonomous quantum physics research using LLM agents with access to intelligent tools
item.content:encoded:
AI, quantum physics, idea generation, large language model, experiment design

Summary: The article introduces AI-Mandel, a large language model (LLM) agent designed to autonomously generate and implement creative scientific ideas in the field of quantum physics. Unlike typical AI applications that rely heavily on human input for initial research questions, AI-Mandel formulates novel ideas from scientific literature and converts them into executable experimental designs using a domain-specific AI tool. This represents a significant step toward automating the entire scientific process, potentially redefining the human role in research. The system has produced scientifically valuable ideas, including new variants of quantum teleportation, primitives for quantum networks with indefinite causal orders, and innovative concepts of geometric phases involving closed loops of quantum information transfer.
